You cannot use any databases as none are setup in the local environment, instead mock a database with an in memory dictionary to store data. No data saved to disk will persist between steps or write operations.

book_club.py: def __init__(self, id=None, name=None, creator=None, members=None, privacy='public'):

steps: 1. Start by setting up the basic structure of the application. This includes creating the main application file (app.py) and setting up a Flask application. Also, create a requirements.txt file to list all the necessary dependencies for the project. The main dependencies will be Flask and pytest. After setting up the basic structure, write a test to ensure that the Flask application is set up correctly and can run without errors.

2. Implement the User class in a separate file (user.py). This class should have attributes for the user's ID, name, email, and password. It should also have methods for creating a new user, authenticating a user, and getting a user's information. After implementing the User class, write tests to ensure that the class methods work as expected.

3. Implement the BookClub class in a separate file (book_club.py). This class should have attributes for the club's ID, name, creator (a User), members (a list of Users), and privacy settings. It should also have methods for creating a new club, adding a member, removing a member, and changing the club's privacy settings. After implementing the BookClub class, write tests to ensure that the class methods work as expected.

4. Implement the Meeting class in a separate file (meeting.py). This class should have attributes for the meeting's ID, date and time, and associated BookClub. It should also have methods for scheduling a new meeting and sending reminders to all club members. After implementing the Meeting class, write tests to ensure that the class methods work as expected.

5. Implement the Forum class in a separate file (forum.py). This class should have attributes for the forum's ID, associated BookClub, and a list of threads. It should also have methods for creating a new thread and adding a comment to a thread. After implementing the Forum class, write tests to ensure that the class methods work as expected.

6. Implement the Thread class in a separate file (thread.py). This class should have attributes for the thread's ID, title, creator (a User), and a list of comments. It should also have methods for adding a comment to the thread. After implementing the Thread class, write tests to ensure that the class methods work as expected.

7. Implement the Comment class in a separate file (comment.py). This class should have attributes for the comment's ID, content, creator (a User), and associated Thread. After implementing the Comment class, write tests to ensure that the class methods work as expected.

8. Implement the VotingSystem class in a separate file (voting_system.py). This class should have attributes for the system's ID, associated BookClub, and a list of book options. It should also have methods for adding a book option, removing a book option, and casting a vote. After implementing the VotingSystem class, write tests to ensure that the class methods work as expected.

9. Implement the Profile class in a separate file (profile.py). This class should have attributes for the profile's ID, associated User, reading list (a list of books), and a list of followers (other Users). It should also have methods for adding a book to the reading list, removing a book from the reading list, and adding a follower. After implementing the Profile class, write tests to ensure that the class methods work as expected.

10. Finally, implement the AdminDashboard class in a separate file (admin_dashboard.py). This class should have attributes for the dashboard's ID and associated User (who must be an admin). It should also have methods for moderating content (e.g., deleting a comment or thread) and managing users (e.g., banning a user). After implementing the AdminDashboard class, write tests to ensure that the class methods work as expected.
step: 6. Implement the Thread class in a separate file (thread.py). This class should have attributes for the thread's ID, title, creator (a User), and a list of comments. It should also have methods for adding a comment to the thread. After implementing the Thread class, write tests to ensure that the class methods work as expected.

First lay out the names of the core classes, functions, methods that will be necessary, As well as a quick comment on their purpose.
Do not comment on what every file does. Please note that the code should be fully functional. No placeholders.

You will start with the "entrypoint" file, then go to the ones that are imported by that file, and so on.
Please note that the code should be fully functional. No placeholders.

Follow a language and framework appropriate best practice file naming convention.
Make sure that files contain all imports, types etc.  The code should be fully functional. Make sure that code in different files are compatible with each other.
When writing code if you are unsure, write a plausible implementation.

Add comments explaining very complex bits of logic.

Python toolbelt preferences:
- pytest
- dataclasses
- flask

Objective:```
### **Virtual Book Club Platform**

**Overview**:
A platform enabling users to create, join, and manage virtual book clubs for reading discussions, meeting scheduling, and book recommendations.

**Functional Requirements to implement**:

1. **Book Club Management**:
   - [ ] 1.1. Users can create or join book clubs.
   - [ ] 1.2. Club creators can set club privacy settings.
   - [ ] 1.3. Club administrators can manage member roles and permissions.

2. **Meeting and Scheduling**:
   - [ ] 2.1. Integrated calendar for scheduling club meetings.
   - [ ] 2.2. Automated reminders for upcoming meetings.

3. **Discussion and Interaction**:
   - [ ] 3.1. Forums for book discussions in each club.
   - [ ] 3.2. Threaded commenting system in forums.
   - [ ] 3.3. Voting system for selecting the club's next book.

4. **User Profiles and Networking**:
   - [ ] 4.1. Personalized profiles for users.
   - [ ] 4.2. Follow system to connect with other readers.
   - [ ] 4.3. Display of users' reading lists and recommendations.

5. **Administration and Analytics**:
   - [ ] 5.1. Dashboard for platform administrators.
   - [ ] 5.2. Tools for content moderation and user management.
   - [ ] 5.3. Analytics on user engagement and popular books.Virtual Book Club Platform
```

Understand the problem, by creating an extremely detailed step-by-step plan, where each step is long (multiple sentences) and in total includes every single feature requirement specified above, feel free to copy directly from it. Use no more than 10 steps in the plan. Create additional tests, checks and evaluation at each step when applicable to help make an excellent code implementation, where all the code is fully functional. Use best software design practices, and you can output large amounts of code at once. Please include a last sentence to create and run tests when implementing or writing code in that same step. You will receive no human input at any stage, so you cannot use a human to test. Only create a detailed plan to begin with, which includes designing and running tests to check that they all pass. Please be sure to include all of the specified feature requirements in the following plan.
